Award.AwardTitle: Developing Bridge Weigh-in-Motion (B-WIM) Health Monitoring Systems for Bridge Infrastructure Safety

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for research on the Next Generation Bridge Weigh-in-Motion (B-WIM) system. This system addresses the bridge safety problem using a two-fold approach: the control of overloaded trucks and the safety assessment/monitoring of bridges. The research will be based on the mathematical modeling of a coupled system of differential equations that represent the dynamic interaction of a moving truck with a bridge while accounting for uncertainties that are due to the unknown road profile and dynamic truck properties. The road profile can be measured but, as it is likely to change over time and the exact transverse location of the truck in its lane is unknown, there is a stochastic component of the system. Therefore, the spring and damping properties of the truck tire and suspension will be treated probabilistically, using a Bayesian Updating approach for the properties of the truck fleet. The difficulties associated with this system when it detects the presence of other smaller vehicles that interfere with the signal will be addressed using a new field of statistics known as the "Classification with a Reject Option". In this way, fleets of vehicles can be simulated to represent a range of situations and the simulations will be complemented by independent field trials for validation purposes.

This project seeks to develop a bridge monitoring and protection system that is effective without being manpower intensive. This project, jointly funded by UK and Ireland funding agencies that leverage the NSF investment, will generate a broad spectrum of spin-off technologies. The potential payoff of this program could be the rapid technology insertion into existing bridge maintenance systems that are needed for much of the bridge stock in the USA and Europe. Moreover, wide deployment of this system has the potential to greatly improve the effectiveness of overload enforcement and to increase road safety for all users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The expansion in highway freight shipments has led to a substantial increase in truck traffic. Of particular concern are the increased number, size and weight of heavy commercial vehicles, often endangering bridges by being illegally overloaded, and causing expensive premature pavement damage. Weigh-in-Motion is the process of weighing trucks while they travel along the road at full speed. This project has two goals: to improve the accuracy of Weigh-in-Motion systems and to develop better methods of detecting damage in bridges. The type of Weigh-in-Motion used in this project is Bridge Weigh-in-Motion (BWIM) – we use sensors on an existing bridge to determine the weights of trucks passing overhead. The major contributions of the project includes: (1) new rigorous algorithms based on probabilistic mathematical modelling of complex dynamic and stochastic systems to achieve a step change increase in accuracy, (2) new methods of axle detection to increase the reliability in detecting and weighing multiple axles and trucks, (3) fully integrated novel sensor network to enable B-WIM to be integrated within the SHM framework and (4) implementation of the new innovations to determine bridge safety.

The development of such tools requires the mathematical modeling of the coupled system of differential equations that represents the dynamic interaction of moving truck and bridge while accounting for uncertainties due to unknown road profile and truck dynamic properties. In the past years, our partners in N. Ireland and UK, assisted by UAB, have implemented innovations that have resulted in significant improvements in the accuracy of the BWIM approach. They have carried out field trials where trucks were weighed on static scales and the weights compared to the results predicted by the BWIM system. New algorithms have been developed by UAB and successfully tested both in the USA and in N. Ireland. A new approach to axle detection has been developed and validated. An innovative dynamic analysis framework based on field data was also investigated to determine the real influence line for the bridge and to estimate the vehicle weight in normal traffic conditions. The proposed new approach involves a site-specific influence line obtained from the field-calibrated simulation model and the dynamic moment obtained from the bridge weigh-in-motion (BWIM) experimental data. Two algorithms for weight calibration were developed to improve the current commercial approach. To this end, the case study of a multi-span simply supported bridge on US-78 demonstrated the improved accuracy of the estimated values of the vehicle weight based on field BWIM data. A particular breakthrough was the development of the first camera-only BWIM system, where a system was developed in which two cameras near a bridge were used to weigh passing trucks. One camera took video pictures of the trucks and identified the speed and the locations of the wheels. The second camera, with the aid of a powerful telescopic lens, took pictures of the bridge and measured its deflection in response to the passing truck. The system is a world first – a completely non-contact method of weighing trucks in motion.

The second part of this project was focused on methods of bridge safety assessment, methods of detecting damage that may have occurred. For bridge Safety Assessment, an ‘apparent profile’ concept has been developed as an indicator of bridge condition/health. It is shown to have good potential as a method of ‘drive-by’ bridge monitoring. The apparent profile is the road surface profile, as calculated from sensor measurements on a specialist passing vehicle.
